column1: Default version of SSL/TLS may be insecure
column2: Leaving the SSL/TLS version unspecified may result in an insecure default protocol being used.
column4: Call to deprecated method ssl.wrap_socket does not specify a protocol, which may result in an insecure default being used.

column2: Using an insecure SSL/TLS version may leave the connection vulnerable to attacks.
column4:
Insecure SSL/TLS protocol version TLSv1 allowed by [["call to ssl.SSLContext"|"relative:///2/sec.py:6:15:6:53"]].
Insecure SSL/TLS protocol version TLSv1_1 allowed by [["call to ssl.SSLContext"|"relative:///2/sec.py:6:15:6:53"]].

column1: Use of a broken or weak cryptographic hashing algorithm on sensitive data
column2: Using broken or weak cryptographic hashing algorithms can compromise security.
column4: [["Sensitive data (certificate)"|"relative:///3/vul.py:3:36:3:46"]] is used in a hashing algorithm (MD5) that is insecure.

column1: Use of a broken or weak cryptographic hashing algorithm on sensitive data
column2: Using broken or weak cryptographic hashing algorithms can compromise security.
column4: [["Sensitive data (password)"|"relative:///4/vul.py:4:23:4:30"]] is used in a hashing algorithm (SHA256) that is insecure for password hashing, since it is not a computationally expensive hash function.

column1: Use of a broken or weak cryptographic algorithm
column2: Using broken or weak cryptographic algorithms can compromise security.
column4: [["The cryptographic algorithm DES"|"relative:///1/vul.py:4:10:4:28"]] is broken or weak, and should not be used.
